subject: Re: Reading practice - The Raven
msgSnippet: Thanks for the feedback! I m enjoying how this is making me more aware of exactly how I talk. Living in central VA, I have a slight southern accent, but my mom
messageBody:
Thanks for the feedback! I'm enjoying how this is making me more
aware of exactly how I talk. Living in central VA, I have a slight
southern accent, but my mom is an Italian from Vermont, so I have
that affecting my speech too!

By the way, I'll go by Paul S from now on, just to avoid confusion.

My resonses to your points are below:

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...>
wrote:
>
> Paul wrote:
> >
> >
> > FYI: I have uploaded to the files a copy of Poe's The Raven I
> > transcribed into QS. I used the converter and went through to
change a
> > few things and clean up in general. My next project is more
ambitious:
> > Jules Verne - 20,000 Leagues Under The Sea
> >
> > Project Gutenberg has plenty of public domain texts in digital
format,
> > and I plan on going through any that interest me.
> >
> > Related to recent posts, I will clarify that I did not use 34 in
the
> > text. I suppose I am odd in that my pronunciation of "on" would
use
> > 33, but "ox" would use 32 ("calm" would also be 33", go figure).
So, I
> > have simply avoided using 34 at all. BYW, I was born and raised
in
> > central Virginia, but don't have much of a "southern" accent.
> >
> > Hope everyone enjoys it, and please let me know of any thing you
feel
> > needs correcting. I went over it several times, but I know I'm
not
> > perfect.
> >
>
> Hi Paul,
>
> I just got around to reading this today. I am not the most perfect
> candidate for seeing problem in the text because I once
memorized "The
> Raven," so I can guess what the words mean without looking at them
> closely, and because I am new to QS.
>
> Mainly I found almost no mistakes in the poem and could sound out
>hte difficult words I had forgotten.
>
> Here's what I think are mistakes:
>
> 1. Shouldn't you use Thither for "the," "Valve" for "of," "Tut"
>for "to" and "It" for "if?" I have come to expect these one letter
>abbreviations (which Read said were a part of QS) when I read a
>text. I actually changed all of these words before I printed out
>the poem so I could read it easier.

I haven't really been using the standard abreviations when using QS
for notes, or the one person I IM. That's something I need to get
used to.

> 2. line 10: you spell "borrow" with the "Ah," which made the words
>hard for me to decipher. I expected "On," or "Awl."



> 3. line 12. The words "for evermore" should be joined? I found
>them joined in one Gutenberg text.

Makes sense to me, but the copy I have from Gutenberg has them
separated, and if that's how Poe wrote it, who am I to edit? Of
course, if that's not how he wrote it, I need to change it, so I
will check a few sources.

> 4. line 33 (and others, too). You spell "shall" with "Ash." I
>expected "Ado," so had a hard time reading the word.

That's just how I say it, rhymes with "Hal".

> 5 line 39 (and others). You spell not with "Ah." I expected "Awl"
>or "On," so was a bit confused.

You're right. I should have used "Awl". That would be closer to how
I pronounce it. It's the old 32-33-34 issue.

> 6. line 40. You have the wrong word. You use an "and"
>between "lord" and "lady" when it should be "or."

"or" would make more sense in the sentence, but "and" is what is in
my copy from Gutenberg. I had to double check after I read your note.

> 7. Line 47 You spell ghastly with "Ash," but I expected "Ah."
>(Is that just my Boston accent?)

Must be your accent! As I say the word, "Ash" is definately more
appropriate.

> 8. line 50 You spell the "not" in cannot with "Ah." I
>expected "Awl."

Again, that's just how I say it. Rhymes with Trent "Lott", or "Mott"
The Hoople

> 9. line 65: You spell "songs" with an "Ah." I expected "On,"
>or "Awe."

You caught me again. I do pronounce it more with "Awe".

> 10. line 70. You spell "ominous" with "Ah." I expected "On,"
>or "Awe."

I do pronounce it with "Ah". Also, remember that for the most part,
32 and 34 are the same, so I just never use 34. I suppose the choice
of 32 is arbitrary. Seems there should be a reason to chose one over
the other, even if you pronounce them both the same.

> 11. line 89. You spell "balm" with "Awl," but I expected "Ah." (My
> Boston accent again?)

It must be my screwy accent. That's just how I pronounce it.

> 12. line 93. You spell "sorrow" with "Ah," when I expected "Awl"
>or "On."

And a third one. I should have used "Awe". I will make the changes
and replace it on the site.

> I see you used my Shawtwo font. How flattering! However, I have
changed
> the name of the font to "Thoth," which you can download in the
files
> section. Since Shawtwo isn't on my system, the document opened and
> displayed TO. I actually typeset the document with TeX and
produced a
> PDF and was thinking of putting it in the text areas on my
sourceforge
> site, with your permission, of course. The PDF version looks much
better
> than the RTF version because the font is kerned correctly, and
with PDF
> anyone can open the document and see it correctly, regardless of
what
> fonts they have on their system.
>
> Paul


I really like the thoth font. I have downloaded that one as well.
You are more then welcome to do whatever you want with it. I did it
in hopes of providing everyone with something else interesting to
practice reading.

Paul S
